text: Anyone have a package for or example of tracking motion in a series of images? I need something like <http://plugins.phage.dk/download/wrMTrck.pdf> but I don't want to use ImageJ...

attachments.title: Celltracker possibilities?
attachments.text: Hi im a student and was wondering if this would be a good language to make a program that tracks cells in a video rather than python or MATLAB. If so I was wondering where I should start. Thanks!

text:
What is ImageJ… that you don’t want? Anyway, I bookmarked this notebook for later use:
<https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/mbauman/TrafficSpeed/blob/master/TrafficSpeed.ipynb>

text:
I made a small package for tracking of blobs (birds in my case) using standard Kalman filters and such
<https://github.com/baggepinnen/BlobTracking.jl|https://github.com/baggepinnen/BlobTracking.jl>
It assumes a dynamical model for the movement of the blobs, and that the blobs are close to circular etc. so it might not be that well suited for tracking weirdly shaped stuff with complex dynamics.

elements.text: I made a small package for tracking of blobs (birds in my case) using standard Kalman filters and such
It assumes a dynamical model for the movement of the blobs, and that the blobs are close to circular etc. so it might not be that well suited for tracking weirdly shaped stuff with complex dynamics.

text: The fact that someone (not me) implemented my algorithm in OpenCV is the sole reason why I have a paper with a four digit number of citations. Hopefully the Julia implementation will help to drive that number in the future.

elements.text: The fact that someone (not me) implemented my algorithm in OpenCV is the sole reason why I have a paper with a four digit number of citations. Hopefully the Julia implementation will help to drive that number in the future.

text: <@UJ7DVTVQ8> ‘s package looks pretty nice and appears to be pretty close to what that ImageJ plug-in does. Julia seems like it would be an excellent language for object tracking since those algorithms frequently use data structures that can’t easily be made fast in Python/Matlab.

elements.text: ‘s package looks pretty nice and appears to be pretty close to what that ImageJ plug-in does. Julia seems like it would be an excellent language for object tracking since those algorithms frequently use data structures that can’t easily be made fast in Python/Matlab.

text: Gunnar, You could also argue that it's because you came up with an algorithm that works and solves peoples problems :wink:

elements.text: Gunnar, You could also argue that it's because you came up with an algorithm that works and solves peoples problems

text: I should mention that BlobTracking.jl was written to solve a particular tracking problem the lab I was working in had, and I am currently not using it. That said, it should work and hopefully be up to date, and the underlying filtering library is being used daily.
